text: guys ready for the the win Scott jerk is
an Ultram marathoner who is known around
the world as one of the toughest and uh
strongest Runners uh ever uh and he's
come to campus to share his thoughts on
plant-based diet and the environmental
impact of veganism people are like you
know you do these crazy 100 mile races
and you're vegan I mean how do you do
that you don't have to just eat twixes
and berries I mean eating a plant-based
diet isn't something that
um boring or dull it's really about
balancing the caloric intake with my
energy output I let a group run with the
triathlon and running club and then in
the evening led a larger group
discussion on the environmental and
health benefits of a plant-based diet
incomes in developing countries are
rising as these societies have become
wealthier they've also increased their
per capita consumption of meat and
between the year 2000 and 2050 Global
meat consumption is forecast to D double
all this is important to understand
because food production creates about a
quarter of all Global greenhouse gas
emissions annually meat production is
especially challenging from an
environmental perspective as it uses
much more land water and antibiotics
than plant production the average meat
consumer's diet is responsible for
2third more Global greenhouse gas
emissions than a vegan's diet going
vegan it wasn't like one day I was you
know eating meat and potatoes and the
next day I went vegan it was a a slow
transition I it took over a year and a
half try a new one new food per week and
incorporate that into one or two meals
they don't have to look at it as a diet
of deprivation you know it's actually
can be fun initially when I got into the
sport it was about you know pushing my
body to the edge and you know winning
and seeing what I could do and now it's
it's really kind of turned into this
lifestyle it's really about longevity
and sustainability I've been doing the
sport for 20 years now um so I would say
I've kind of evolved as an athlete
